Key terms and definitions.What are primary cells: Non-rechargeable electrochemical cells in which a chemical reaction generates electrical energy
Key terms and definitions.What are secondary cells: Rechargeable electrochemical cells in which a chemical reaction generates electrical energy
Key terms and definitions.What is meant by the term 'recharge': The conversion of electrical energy into electrical energy through redox reactions with the aid of an external power supply
Key terms and definitions.What is meant by the term 'discharge': The conversion of chemical energy to electrical energy as a result of spontaneous redox reactions

Primary cells.Why are primary cells problematic: As they cannot be recharged, they produce a lot of potentially harmful waste
Primary cells.True/False: Primary cells can undergo re: False, they can undergo discharge only
Primary cells.What factors prevent primary cells from:
In order for a cell to be recharged it must meet the following conditions: 
- The products of the cell reaction must remain in contact with their electrodes 
- The products must be in a form that allows it to be converted back to its original reactant form 
- An external power supply must be present to drive the non-spontaneous redox reactions

Secondary cells.Why must secondary cells be connected to: The reactions required to convert the products of the discharge back to their reactant form are non-spontaneous reactions. And as such a source of energy is required to drive these reactions
Secondary cells.True/False: Secondary cells require a po: False, they require a power supply with a voltage higher than that of the cell

Factors affecting battery life and capac.How do low temperatures effect battery c: As the temperature decreases, so does the capacity of the battery because the cell reaction rate decreases, producing less electrical energy

- Temperature 
- Reactants and products migrating away from their electrodes 
- Side reactions converting reactants and products to inactive forms 
- Side reactions forming chemicals that inferfere with cell functioning 
- Corrosion of internal components 
- Leakage of the electrolyte

All.What is a fuel: A substance that is used, usually combusted, that has energy stored in its bonds
All.What is a fossil fuel: A natural fuel that is formed in the Earth from plant or animal remains
All.What is coal: A combustible fossil fuel formed by the partial decay of plant matter
All.What is petrodiesal: A liquid hydrocarbon fossil fuel obtained from crude oil
All.What is natural gas: A fossil fuel consisting largely of hydrocarbons
All.What is coal seam gas: A natural gas sourced from coal deposits
All.What is the greenhouse effect: The process of the warming of Earths lower atmosphere due to the increased quantities of gases, like carbon dioxide, water vapour and methane, in the air
All.What is a non-renewable resource: A resource that cannot be replenished as quickly as it is being consumed
All.What is petroleum/crude oil: A mixture of hydrocarbons that need to be seperated and possibly treated to produce desired products

All.What are the three steps in the forming:
1: Vegetation dies to form peat (60% carbon) 
2: Peat is compressed between sediment to form brown coal (70% carbon)
3: Brown coal is further compressed to form black coal (90% carbon)
All.True/False: Brown coal is the most energ: False, black coal has a higher carbon percentage of 90%
All.Outline the steps involved in converting:
1: Coal is combusted 
2: The heat produced is used to boil water, forming steam 
3: The steam is used to turn a turbine that produces electrical energy
All.True/False: Petroleum/crude oil deposits: False, these deposits are very often contaminated

All.How is natural gas accessed: Drilling and a process known as fracking
All.Outline the process of fracking: Fracking involves the injecting of high pressure liquid into coal and shale rocks to force open fissures to extract the gas
All.Why are fossil fuels considered non-rene: They cannot be produced as fast as they are being consumed, as the process of fossilisation takes a long time

All.What is chemical energy: Energy that is stored in the bonds of chemical compounds
All.What is meant by 'exothermic': A chemical reaction accompanied by the release of energy in the form of heat
All.What is meant by 'endothermic': A chemical reaction that absorbs energy in the form of heat from the surrounding environment
All.What is enthalpy: A measurement of the internal energy of a system
All.What is meant by 'complete combustion': The reaction of a substance with oxygen to produce carbon dioxide and water
All.What is meant by 'incomplete combustion': The partial burning of a substance to produce carbon monoxide and water
All.True/False: Complete combustion occurs w: False, it is the opposite way around
All.True/False: All combustion reactions are: False, they release heat energy and as such are classified as exothermic
All.Compare the enthalpy of the reactants an: Combustions reactions are exothermic, meaning that energy was lost to the surroundings during the reaction. Therefore the reactants of the combustion reactions will have a greater combined enthalpy than that of the products
All.Why is the change in enthalpy of all exo: All exothermic reactions release energy into their surrondings during the reaction process, meaning that there is a net loss of energy from the system and hence a negative change in enthalpy
All.Compare the enthalpy of the reactants an: During endothermic reactions there is a net gain in energy by the system, meaning that the reactants will have a lower enthalpy value than their products
